newsitem.title: USA: U.S. money managers lower cash positions -- MCM.
newsitem.headline: U.S. money managers lower cash positions -- MCM.

text.p: U.S. fixed-income managers held their dollar-weighted durations on their debt portfolios mostly steady, but cash positions dropped for the second consecutive week, an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey said.
"Cash positions fell further ... but are still above the December (1996) lows," said MCM MoneyWatch vice president Astrid Adolfson, who conducts the weekly survey.
The drop may be attributed to quarter-end "windowdressing," because both ends of the yield curve became overweighted, Adolfson added.
In the week ending June 30, durations as a percentage of benchmark inched lower to 108.0 from 108.1 percent.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 32 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," unchanged from the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" held steady at 19 percent.
Forty-nine percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 2.75 percent from 2.84 percent registered the previous week.
The survey showed 33 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, up from 31 percent the previous week, while 9.0 percent underweighted it.
The remaining 58 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 50 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 11 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
